record.attribute:
Community Ourtreach Specialist

    The Eukaryotic Pathogen Database resource (EuPathDB.org) seeks to hire a community outreach specialist with a focus on fungal biology. The outreach team (three plus members) works collaboratively within a larger ~30-member team of biologists, annotators, user-interface and software developers to provide effective data representation and online resources to scientists and clinicians worldwide who utilize the highly-visible EuPathDB websites.
    These sites include those for malaria-causing parasites (PlasmoDB.org), trypanosomes (TriTrypDB.org), fungi (FungiDB.org) and other pathogenic eukaryotic organisms. The overall project goal is to present our global user base with an intuitive and informative Web interface for accessing and interrogating omic-scale datasets. The successful applicant must be able to effectively communicate with scientists conducting various types of research on pathogenic eukaryotes and their close relatives in order to respond to the communities' needs and identify/acquire omic-scale datasets. Thus, effective communication and an understanding of the challenges posed by large-scale data are required. The position requires travel with active participation in scientific meetings including internationally, instruction at workshops and webinars, participation in scientific writing of abstracts, manuscripts and other material (ie. Posters, flyers and educational material), and keeping up-to-date with the pertinent scientific literature.

One position is open in three possible locations:

Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA

Athens, Georgia, USA

The United Kingdon (position to be announced soon)

We are pleased to announce the release of FungiDB 26

New data in this release

The data set title below links to a full description and list of associated searches and GBrowse tracks.

Genome Sequence and Annotation: the following genomes were updated to the current Genbank versions

  • Ustilago maydis 521 — genome sequence and annotation updated to Genbank version 18 Feb 2015.
  • Coccidioides posadasii C735 delta SOWgp — genome sequence and annotation updated to Genbank version 17 June 2009.
  • Coccidioides posadasii Silveira — genome sequence and annotation updated to Genbank version 25 Jan 2011.
  • Coccidioides posadasii RMSCC3488 — genome sequence and annotation updated to Genbank version 18 July 2007.

New Genome Sequence: available for the first time in FungiDB:

  • Coccidioides immitis RMSCC 2394 — Genbank version 11 Feb 2006.
  • Coccidioides immitis RMSCC 3703 — Genbank version 18 July 2007.
  • Coccidioides posadasii CPA 0001 — Genbank version 19 Nov 2007.
  • Coccidioides posadasii CPA 0020 — Genbank version 30 Jan 2008.
  • Coccidioides posadasii CPA 0066 — Genbank version 7 Feb 2008.
  • Coccidioides posadasii RMSCC 1037 — Genbank version 30 Jan 2008.
  • Coccidioides posadasii RMSCC 1038 — Genbank version 30 Jan 2008.
  • Coccidioides posadasii RMSCC 2133 — Genbank version 19 Nov 2007.
  • Coccidioides posadasii RMSCC 3700 — Genbank version 19 Nov 2007.

New Features

GBrowse Track Search

  • The Select Tracks page in the Genome Browser now includes a search function. Search for specific tracks based on a word or phrase from the track title or category. image

New Tutorials

  • Find genes with an enriched GO term
  • Downloading untranslated regions of genes
  • Download sequence for genes in a search result
  • Downloading sequence from a gene page
  • Download the sequence of all genes for an organism
  • Download the Sequence (fasta) and Annotation (gff) files for a genome
  • Downloading coding sequence
  • Downloading protein sequence
Note: Our bimonthly database releases incorporate new data and correct old data when necessary. Changes in annotation and new experimental data may slightly alter your search results by increasing or decreasing the number of hits. When search parameters change with a new release, we invalidate (Ø) the search and ask you to rerun it. When IDs are updated or removed, we map the old IDs to the new ones, remove the old IDs from your Basket, and leave your Favorites page alone.

We are pleased to announce the release of FungiDB 25

New data in this release

The data set title below links to a full description and list of associated searches and GBrowse tracks.

Genome Sequence and Annotation

  • Aspergillus oryzae RIB40 — AspGD version 13 April 2015. Genome sequence and annotation for this organism are available for the first time in FungiDB.

Curated Phenotypes

  • Curated Cryptococcus Phenotypes — Phenotypes curated from the literature by Diane Inglis are available in tabulated form on the gene pages of 446 genes from Cryptococcus gattii strains WM276 and R265, Cryptpcoccus neoformans var. neoformans JEC21, var. grubii H99, and var. neoformans B-3501A.
Note: Our bimonthly database releases incorporate new data and correct old data when necessary. Changes in annotation and new experimental data may slightly alter your search results by increasing or decreasing the number of hits. When search parameters change with a new release, we invalidate (Ø) the search and ask you to rerun it. When IDs are updated or removed, we map the old IDs to the new ones, remove the old IDs from your Basket, and leave your Favorites page alone.

We are pleased to announce the release of FungiDB 24
All EuPathDB release numbers have been synchronized to help us more efficiently manage our expanding number of databases.  As of this release all EuPathDB resource release numbers have been set to release 24.  Subsequent version numbers will increase by one with each release.  For information about individual dataset version numbers see the Data Sets page.
EuPathDB
Resource		 Jan 2015
Version #
 April 2015
Version #
FungiDB 3.2 24
New Features:

Help us improve our Data Set page: The dataset page includes information about all datasets loaded into our resources including, release and date loaded, name of the provider, links to searches and data visualization, etc... Take a look at the beta version of our dataset page (access it from the data summary menu item at the top of our web pages) and let us know what you think.


Note: Our bimonthly database releases incorporate new data and correct old data when necessary.  Changes in annotation and new experimental data may slightly alter your search results by increasing or decreasing the number of hits. When search parameters change with a new release, we invalidate (Ø) the search and ask you to rerun it. When IDs are updated or removed, we map the old IDs to the new ones, remove the old IDs from your Basket, and leave your Favorites page alone.

Follow EuPathDB on FaceBook, Twitter, and YouTube

We are pleased to release FungiDB 3.2.  This release include the following new data and features.

New Data:

  • Genomes and annotation (full description and attribution is available in the dataset section):

    • Pneumocystis carinii
    • Zymoseptoria tritici
    • Pythium ultimum var. sporangiiferum
    • Pythium irregulare
    • Pythium iwayamai
    • Pythium arrhenomanes
    • Pythium aphanidermatum
    • Pythium vexans
    • Saprolegnia diclina
    • Aphanomyces astaci
    • Aphanomyces invadans
    • Albugo candida
    • Albugo laibachii


  • High throughput sequencing data from drug-resistant and susceptible clinical and environmental isolates of Aspergillus fumigatus.  Sequencing data was aligned to the reference genome A. fumigatus Af293 and single nucleotide polyorphisms were determined. To run searches against this data, visit the data set section for a full description and links to searches.   

  • RNA sequencing data from 3 Phytophthora sojae samples: media grown, cysts, and from infected soybean hypocotyls.  Additional information and links to searches can be viewed in the dataset section.  


New feature:
  • Results analysis tools:  results of any searches can now be analyzed for statistical enrichment or Gene Ontology (GO) terms, metabolic pathways or gene product text terms. A detailed description of this new functionality and a video tutorial are also available.


Note: Our bimonthly database releases incorporate new data and correct old data when necessary.  Changes in annotation and new experimental data may slightly alter your search results by increasing or decreasing the number of hits. When search parameters change with a new release, we invalidate (Ø) the search and ask you to rerun it. When IDs are updated or removed, we map the old IDs to the new ones, remove the old IDs from your Basket, and leave your Favorites page alone.

Follow EuPathDB on FaceBook, Twitter, and YouTube
Open letter to the Aspergillus research community

An open letter to the Aspergillus research community on genome database resources:

    As many of you may already be aware, the NIH R01 research grant that has supported development of the AspGD database will not be renewed ... not because the NIH doesn't appreciate the value and importance of this resource to the Aspergillus research community, but because the current funding climate makes it difficult to support curation-intensive databases serving individual pathogens and relatively small research communities. However, NIH has provided one year of funding to ensure that information from AspGD is integrated into FungiDB, a component of the EuPathDB Bioinformatics Resource Center. We do not anticipate that AspGD will disappear: you should still be able to access the existing web site, at least for the foreseeable future, but curatorial engagement will have to be significantly reduced over the coming months.

    The EuPathDB family of databases supports a wide range of microbial eukaryotes, including protozoan parasites and many fungal and oomycete species, including non-pathogens. This resource has been specifically designed to provide sustainable, cost-effective automated analysis of multiple genomes, integrating curated information where available, along with comments and supporting evidence from the user community (PubMedIDs, phenotypic information, images, datasets, etc). In addition to gene records, browser views, and data downloads, FungiDB also provides a variety of sophisticated tools for integrating and mining diverse Omics datasets, which we expect that Aspergillus researchers and other fungal biologists will find quite useful. See sidebar on the FungiDB web site for access to tutorials, videos, and exercises; more fungi-specific materials should become available over the coming months.

    AspGD and FungiDB/EuPathDB will be working together to maximize value to the Aspergillus community, given the limited resources available. The upcoming AsperFest12 and 28th Fungal Genetics meetings in Asilomar (March 16-22, 2015) will be attended by staff from both groups, with presentations and a 'help-desk' to introduce the Aspergillus community to FungiDB. We look forward to productive discussions on how to ensure that Aspergillus researchers retain access to information from AspGD, learn to use FungiDB effectively and have a voice in its further development, and craft a strategy for meeting future informatics needs.

  • Jessica Kissinger (Univ Georgia) -- Joint-PI, EuPathDB
  • Michelle Momany (Univ Georgia) -- Community Liaison, AspGD & FungiDB
  • David Roos (Univ Pennsylvania) -- Joint-PI, EuPathDB; Co-PI, FungiDB
  • Gavin Sherlock (Stanford Univ) -- Principal Investigator, AspGD
  • Jason Stajich (UC Riverside) -- Principal Investigator, FungiDB
  • Jennifer Wortman (Broad Inst) -- Co-PI, AspGD

Dear colleagues -

We are writing to provide an update on the Eukaryotic Pathogen Genomics Resource (EuPathDB.org), which many hundreds of laboratories wrote to support in connection with our application for renewal as an NIH Bioinformatics Resource Center for Infectious Diseases.  We are pleased to report that the EuPathDB contract has now been renewed.

In addition to continuing to integrate the ever-increasing volume of Omic-scale datasets available for microbial eukaryotes, new functionalities anticipated over the coming months include:

  • full integration of FungiDB into the EuPathDB family of databases
  • reorganization of EuPathDB record pages, so as to improve navigability, better accommodate curated annotation (when available), represent alternative transcripts, summarize functional genomic results, etc
  • better representation of experimental metadata, including phenotyping and clinical/field results
  • enhanced functionality of the host response database (HostDB.org)
  • improved handling of metabolic pathways, including incorporation of metabolomic datasets
  • better support for orthology-based queries and cross-species inference
  • implementation of workspaces enabling users to upload and analyze their own data (e.g. RNA-seq results)


The scope of this renewal extends beyond our previous mandate, which officially covered only biosecurity threats (Cryptosporidium, Entamoeba, Giardia, Toxoplasma, etc) and reemerging pathogens (e.g. Plasmodium).  This makes it easier for us to leverage EuPathDB infrastructure in support of the kinetoplastida, oomycetes, fungi, and other microbial eukaryotes, including both pathogenic and non-pathogenic species.

The scale of the EuPathDB award from NIH does not provide adequate funding for full support of the TriTrypDB or FungiDB projects (unfortunately) ... but the Wellcome Trust has agreed to consider an application covering these initiatives, augmenting our existing award for kinetoplastid resources.  We will be contacting users of these databases shortly for their support.

As always, we look forward to feedback from database users, via the 'Contact Us' link on all EuPathDB web sites, face-to-face discussions at major meetings, etc.

Brian P. Brunk -- EuPathDB Senior Project Manager
Christiane Hertz-Fowler -- Kinetoplastid Resources PI (on behalf of UK co-PIs)
Omar S. Harb -- EuPathDB Scientific Outreach Manager
Jessica C. Kissinger -- EuPathDB joint-PI
David S. Roos -- EuPathDB joint-PI, Kinetoplastid Resources co-PI, FungiDB co-PI
Jason E. Stajich -- FungiDB co-PI
Christian J. Stoeckert -- EuPathDB co-PI

FungiDB 3.1 is released this month.

Updates

14 RNA-Seq datasets are added for a total of 22 datasets.

2 Microarray datasets are now available.

Corrections

SC25 of Cryptococcus gattii R265 - SC25 changed to mitochondrial

Corrected the exon phase interpretation of several JGI genomes:

  • Aspergillus aculeatus ATCC 16872
  • Mucor circinelloides f. lusitanicus
  • Phycomyces blakesleeanus NRRL 1555(-)
  • Phytophthora capsici
  • Phanerochaete chrysosporium
  • Phytophthora ramorum Pr-102
  • Pythium ultimum DAOM BR144
  • Tremella mesenterica DSM 1558

Known issues

HTS SNPs remain unavailable until the next point release.

This release of FungiDB 3.0 adds 12 new genomes for a total of 64 in the database.

New species include:

  • Aspergillus niger CBS 513.88
  • Aspergillus aculeatus ATCC 16872
  • Candida glabrata CBS 138
  • Melampsora larici-populina 98AG31
  • Yarrowia lipolytica CLIB122
  • Pneumocystis jirovecii SE8
  • Allomyces macrogynus ATCC 38327
  • Spizellomyces punctatus DAOM BR117
  • Phycomyces blakesleeanus NRRL 1555(-)
  • Phytophthora parasitica INRA-310
  • Phytophthora cinnamomi var. cinnamomi CBS 144.22
  • Saprolegnia parasitica CBS 223.65

Mitochondrial contigs were added for:

  • Aspergillus clavatus NRRL 1
  • Cryptococcus neoformans var. grubii H99
  • Cryptococcus gattii R265
  • Rhizopus delemar RA 99-880
  • Allomyces macrogynus ATCC 38327

Updates

17 genomes were updated:

  • Aspergillus fumigatus Af293 - AspGD s03-m04-r13
  • Aspergillus nidulans FGSC A4 - AspGD s10-m01-r07
  • Talaromyces marneffei ATCC 18224 - Genbank 2009-08-26
  • Botryotinia fuckeliana B05.10 - Genbank 2009-08-10
  • Candida albicans SC5314 - CGD A21-s02-m07-r06
  • Saccharomyces cerevisiae S288c - SGD 2013-07-12
  • Schizosaccharomyces pombe 972h- - Pombase 2.20
  • Neurospora crassa OR74A - Broad 12
  • Tremella mesenterica DSM 1558 - JGI 1
  • Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici CRL75-36-700-3 - Broad 2
  • Ustilago maydis 521 - MIPS 2013-04-19
  • Phytophthora infestans T30-4 - Broad 1
  • Phytophthora ramorum Pr-102 - JGI 1.1
  • Phytophthora sojae P6497 - JGI 3
  • Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis Emoy2 - Ensembl 2013-12-07
  • Pythium ultimum DAOM BR144 - JCVI 2013-07-16

Known issues

Several RNASeq and Microarray datasets from the previous release are not available, but will be reloaded in the next point release.

FungiDB 2.3 is released this month. The total genomes included in the release is now 52.

New genomes included in this release include

  • Botrytis cinerea
  • Sclerotinia sclerotiorum
  • Aspergillus carbonarius
  • Neosartorya fischeri
  • Trichoderma reesei
  • Schizosaccharomyces japonicus
  • Schizosaccharomyces octosporus
  • Phanerochaete chrysosporium
  • Sporisorium reilianum
  • Malassezia globosum
  • Mucor circinelloides f. lusitanicus

Mitochondrial genomes were added for the following organisms

  • Aspergillus fumigatus
  • Neurospora crassa
  • Saccharomyces cerevisiae
  • Schizosaccharomyces japonicus
  • Schizosaccharomyces octosporus

New genomics data available in this release include additional RNA-Seq experiments for Coprinopsis cinerea. High Throughput SNP (HTS) discovery module have been added for Aspergillus fumigatus and a population of 23 strains from JCVI.

Data fixes and update

Updated in this release include new versions of annotation for

  1. Aspergillus fumigatus - s03-m02-r18 from AspGD
  2. Aspergillus nidulans - s09-m05-r03 from AspGD
  3. Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. lycopersici - correcting some annotation problems in Broad v2
  4. Neurospora discreta - correcting some annotation problems from JGI
  5. Saccharomyces cerevisiae version from 2012-11-20

The current annotation for N. crassa is still v10 release and does not reflect the V12 release made March 2013. The updated version will be available in the 3.0 release of FungiDB.

Corrections

The Coccidioides RNA-Seq data in the previous release had flipped the labels of the spherule and mycelium results, this has been corrected.

Errors in previous loading of gene product information for P. sojae had left many genes without sufficient product information and description. This has been corrected.

Synteny results between several species were not properly loaded in the previous release. This has been corrected.

Data summary tables of genomes and gene metrics have been updated to reflect the current state of the database.

Known errors

Alternative splicing and starting/ending non-coding exons may not be properly represented in GBrowse and in the GFF files available for download.

FungiDB 2.1 is released and includes 39 Fungal genomes from Ascomycota, Basidiomycota, and Mucormycotina (Zygomycota) and 6 genomes of Oomycetes. This release builds on the 2.0 release from August to include 6 additional species, RNA-Seq from a population of Neurospora strains, growth time points in 3 fungi Coprinopsis, Neurospora, and Rhizopus, and Phytophthora species. The 6 new genomes include Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, Coprinopsis cinereus, Histoplasma capsulatum, Coccidioides posadasii, Rhizopus oryzae (R. delemar), and Ustilago maydis.

The 2.0 release, with 31 genomes including 6 Oomycetes was released at fungidb.org.The release includes improved view of the lists of species, links to OrthoMCL, inclusion of Microarray and RNA-Seq datasets from C.albicans, S. cerevisiae, N. crassa, S.pombe, and P. ramorum. The inclusion of the Oomycetes represents a collaboration with Brett Tyler's group at Oregon State University. This is the first full release using new workflow and data analysis pipeline that has incorporated automation into the system. This release of FungiDB includes 31 genomes of Fungi and Oomycetes.


The following Genomes are now available via FungiDB:
  • Eurotiomycetes; Ascomycota
    • Aspergillus clavatus
    • Aspergillus flavus
    • Aspergillus fumigatus strain Af293

    • Coccidoidies immitis strain H538.4
  • Sordariomycetes; Ascomyocta

    • Gibberella moniliformis (Fusarium verticillioides)
    • Magnaporthea oryzae
    • Neurospora crassa strain OR74A
    • Neurospora tetrasperma
    • Neurospora discreta
    • Sordaria macrospora
  • Taphrinomycotina; Ascomyocta
    • Schizosaccharomyces pombe
  • Saccharomycotina; Ascomyocta
    • Candida albicans

  • Basidiomycota
    • Cryptococcus neoformans var. grubii) strain H99
    • Cryptococcus neoformans var. neoformans) strain JEC21

    • Cryptococcus gattii strain WM276
    • Cryptococcus gattii strain R265
    • Tremella mesenterica
  • Oomycetes; Stramenopiles
    • Phytophthora capsici
    • Phytophthora infestans
    • Phytophthora ramorum

    • Pythium ultimatum

The 2.0 alpha release, with 8 genomes, from 5 Cryptococcus, Tremella mesenterica, Neurospora crassa, and Saccharomyces cerevisiae were released at alpha.fungidb.org. This is a pre-release using new workflow and data analysis pipeline. It will soon follow with additional species that incorporate the previously released genomes.

A short blog post at the Hyphal Tip is up to demonstrate how comment pages can be used to add annotation for a gene record page. This is useful way to allow community annotation, registering of gene names, and linking of publication and sequence records to gene pages. The comments page can also be used for listing negative results (e.g. "Knockout has no phenotype") and describing gene model improvements (e.g. "Intron 3 is wrong, the correct exon locations are Chr3: 1020-1401, 1521-1703").

We are pleased to announce the release of FungiDB 1.0 beta


This release of FungiDB includes 18 genomes of 17 species of Fungi in Ascomycete, Basidiomycete, and Zygomycota


The following Fungal Genomes are now available via FungiDB:
  • Eurotiomycetes; Ascomycota
    • Aspergillus clavatus
    • Aspergillus flavus
    • Aspergillus fumigatus strain Af293
    • Aspergillus niger
    • Aspergillus nidulans (Emericella nidulans) strain A4
    • Aspergillus terreus
    • Coccidoidies immitis strain RS
    • Coccidoidies immitis strain H538.4
  • Sordariomycetes; Ascomyocta
    • Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. lycopersici
    • Gibberella zeae (Fusarium graminearum)
    • Gibberella moniliformis (Fusarium verticillioides)
    • Magnaporthea oryzae formerly (Magnaporthe grisea)
    • Neurospora crassa strain OR74A
  • Saccharomycotina; Ascomyocta
    • Candida albicans
    • Saccharomyces cerevisiae
  • Basidiomycota
    • Filobasidiella neoformans (Cryptococcus neoformans var. grubii) strain H99
    • Puccinia graminis
  • Mucormycotina ("Zygomycota")
    • Rhizopus oryzae
